10.text:
We found that in essence we are at a make-or-break
point for the future of the UK and its economy

18.text:
and its workforce and its people. We are approaching,
entering a period of rapid technological change;

25.text:
there’s lots written about it all the time
in the media, we received compelling and wide-ranging

29.text:
evidence which all pointed to the enormity
of the changes ahead.

33.text:
We have a choice as a country about whether
we seize the opportunity or whether we slightly

38.text:
take our foot off the pedal and do enough
to stay in the game but not to be one of the

44.text:
best, and we’re clear that we must seize
this opportunity.

50.text:
There’s going to be significant changes
in the workforce, workforce and the jobs that

58.text:
are going to be available to British people
in the future. A whole range of jobs that

63.text:
we know now will change will be effectively
done by technology they won't be done by people

69.text:
anymore. That means we've got to look at making
sure that we’re skilling children at school,

73.text:
our current workforce, looking ahead to the
future to make sure that people can seize

78.text:
the opportunities and will be trained and
ready to do the jobs that will come in the

81.text:
future.
The starting point that we were very clear

91.text:
about is that the internet now, and use of
the internet, in effect needs to be seen as

96.text:
a utility. We all know that we expect everybody
to be able to access water or electricity,

102.text:
we feel that going forward everybody actually
has to have access to the internet. So that’s

107.text:
our starting point.
That then leads to groups of people who don't

111.text:
have access to the internet, some because
actually the technology’s not quite working,

115.text:
and there are parts of the country where that's
an issue. But there are also groups who either

120.text:
have never have never been trained in use
of the internet, haven't got the skill base

123.text:
necessary or can't afford the very basic package
that allows you to have access to the internet.

131.text:
There are obvious particular groups that I
think people are generally aware of, the older

135.text:
parts of the population tend to be less digitally
connected, some parts of the country are less

141.text:
digitally connected, there is an issue around
poverty. There’s also though a skill issue,

147.text:
and we were quite concerned to hear that 18
to 24-year-olds are actually not doing as

153.text:
well as we might hope in comparison to our
European competitors.

159.text:
The issue that came through extremely strongly
was the choices that are made by girls when

168.text:
they’re choosing GCSE subjects which means
that when they get onto A level they're already

172.text:
excluded from certain subjects. When you get
to higher education, STEM subjects, science,

179.text:
technology, engineering, maths, are very disproportionately
dominated by men rather than women and then

186.text:
quite naturally that then follows through
to careers. So we were really clear that there’s

191.text:
a great opportunity, actually, for the UK
if we started to skill up our women, and we

195.text:
particularly started to make sure that girls
at an early age realize the wide range of

200.text:
careers that demand a level of digital skill
and of science and technology subjects we

205.text:
could actually have quite a transformative
effect on the economy.

216.text:
We've got a range of conclusions around education.
The first one is that we welcome the coding

221.text:
curriculum that's been introduced into schools;
we are concerned though about the training

225.text:
of teachers and the up-skilling of teachers
who perhaps have been teaching for quite a

230.text:
long time – so there’s a big area of work
to be done on that. And we also think that

235.text:
- while we completely support the continued
focus on literacy and numeracy and that was

241.text:
very clear to us in all the evidence we received,
that is the foundation - that actually digital

247.text:
skills have to be taught alongside literacy
and numeracy in the future and we really would

252.text:
encourage government to look seriously at
making sure that not just not just the coding

257.text:
curriculum but wider digital skills are introduced
properly throughout pupils’ school lives.

268.text:
We want this to be a wake-up call for the
new Government after May, whoever, whatever

272.text:
combination that is - it’s for the new Government.
It’s not a massive critique of what’s

277.text:
been there in the past, there’s quite a
lot of good work happened, What we are really

281.text:
clear about is there needs to be a comprehensive
digital agenda that covers all of Government

287.text:
and is lead from the top of Government. This
needs to be at the heart of Government, it’s

292.text:
got be joined up properly and there’s got
to be a completely renewed focus of activity.
